dsls.description: Welcome to CS Fundamentals! These projects were all created with Sprite Lab. Try them out now to see what is possible. By the end of this course, you will be able to make your own projects like these... and more!
dsls.teacher_markdown:
# Choice Level Overview
Choice levels provide a menu of additional levels for students to complete. Students must complete at least one of the sub-levels here, but may work through as many as they (or you) like.

The choices here take students to sample apps that they can explore. This activity is intended to coordinate with the Exploring Apps worksheet, found in the [lesson plan](.././).

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make a prediction!
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
Make a prediction! Study the code.

-   Both planes will move one space along the grid.
-   Both planes will start moving and not stop.
-   One plane will move first, and the other plane will move second.
-   The planes will crash.

answers.text: Both planes will move one space along the grid, then stop.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. These sprites have "behaviors" which keep running until they are told to stop.

answers.text: Both planes will start moving and not stop.
answers.feedback: Correct! These behaviors tell the planes to start moving and keep going.

answers.text: One plane will move first, and the other plane will move later.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Each block of code in Sprite Lab runs instantly after the next.

answers.text: The planes will crash.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The planes are not positioned in a way that will make them touch.

questions.text: Read the code, then make a prediction.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make a sprite.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Making Sprites
[expandable][0]
To make a sprite, open the **Sprites** category of the toolbox and drag out this block: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Connect a `make new sprite` block under the `when run` block. - Choose a costume for your sprite. - Press the "Run" button when your code is finished.

callouts.sprites_category: Click here to open the Sprites category.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Practice making sprites and choosing their locations.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Choose a new position for your sprite on the screen.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Positioning Sprites Each sprite has a **location**. You can set the location by clicking the pin on this block: [blockly block][0] ## Do This
[expandable][1]
- Find the new block in the **Locations** category of the toolbox and drag it into your workspace. - Connect it to the `make new sprite` block you added before. - Click the pin [][2] on the location block then choose a new position for your sprite on the screen. - Press Run when you are finished with your code.

callouts.locations_category: Click here to open the Locations category.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Practice making sprites and choosing their locations.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make four sprites.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# More Sprites Now, let's add even more sprites to this program. ## Do This
[expandable][0]
- Click the image to the right to expand it. - Make four sprites. Choose any costumes you like. - Position each one in a different corner of the screen like the image.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Learn to change the size of sprites.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Use the new block in the Sprites category to change the size of the second sprite.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Sprite Properties Sprites have more properties, including a **size** that can be set with code. Here are two sprites, but one is larger than the other. Use the new block in the **Sprites** category to change the size of the second sprite. ## Do This
[expandable][0]
- Use a `set size` block to resize the second sprite. You can make it bigger or smaller. _Hint:_ The default sprite size is 100, so choose any other number.

callouts.sprites_category2: Look for a new block here.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Give a sprite a behavior.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Behaviors Sprites can have their own behaviors, which are actions they will do over and over while the program runs. To give a sprite a behavior, you need to use a `sprite begins` block with a behavior block. ## Do This
[expandable][0][expandable][1][expandable][2]
- Drag out a `sprite begins` block from the **Behaviors** toolbox category. - Drag out a green behavior block. Connect the blocks in your workspace. - Press "Run" to see what happens. - Explore different behaviors to see what they do. - _Challenge:_ Have your sprite begin two different behaviors at the same time.

callouts.behaviors_category: Click here to open the Behaviors category.

courseF_sprites_desert.bubble_choice_description: Create a scene. Practice making sprites and choosing their locations.
courseF_sprites_desert.short_instructions: Add code to create a desert scene with different sprites.
courseF_sprites_desert.long_instructions:
# Desert Scene
![expandable](https://images.code.org/cf86ddb8f8dc5250bef58dae339b75f7-image-1610467689405.png)
Add code to create a desert scene with different sprites. You can click the picture to the right for an example. ## Do This * Make four sprites. Choose any costumes you like. * Position each one in a different corner of the screen. ![expandable](https://images.code.org/ad153591fa3c233050d51200bce2a1c2-image-1610468037688.png) * Change the size of your sprites to make your final image look more realistic.

courseF_place_fruit.bubble_choice_description: The strawberries are too big! Practice resizing sprites.
courseF_place_fruit.short_instructions: Change the size of the sprites so the banana is bigger than the strawberries.
courseF_place_fruit.long_instructions:
# Sprite Sizes
![expandable](https://images.code.org/f9b425ca22fea885936155bc772e9c5b-image-1610393644593.png)
Code to create strawberry and banana sprites is below, but the sprites are the wrong size. Change the size of the sprites so the banana is bigger than the strawberries. ## Do This * Add two `set size` blocks to the program.
Where is this block?This block is in the Sprites category of the toolbox. "scale""face_strawberry_1"50
* Make the strawberry sprites smaller. * Make the banana sprite bigger. *Hint:* The default size is 100.

courseF_sprites_ship.bubble_choice_description: Practice moving sprites and using behaviors.
courseF_sprites_ship.short_instructions: Make a ship sprite and have it sail across the water.
courseF_sprites_ship.long_instructions:
# Animate a sailing ship
![expandable](https://images.code.org/62944c2ca1bfcebde89ac410bc772ef0-image-1610381772255.2021-01-11 11_15_36.gif)
Make a ship sprite and have it sail across the water. ## Do This * Make a new ship sprite. * Move the sprite so it sits upon the water. * Make the sprite move across the screen with a behavior. * *Bonus:* Use a second behavior, such as "wobbling" or "fluttering", to make the ship more life-like as it moves.

courseF_sprites_clouds.short_instructions: Make the cloud move across the screen. Make the sun spin. Make the butterfly wander around.
courseF_sprites_clouds.long_instructions:
# A Breezy Day
![expandable](https://images.code.org/bd7f7bb8b6e56028ad7f6c7ef8ac7eb8-image-1610401074711.gif)
There is already code to create the sprites. Add to this program to give each sprite a behavior. ## Do This * Add a `sprite begins` block for each sprite costume in your program. * Pick behaviors for each sprite: * Make the cloud move across the screen. * Make the sun spin. * Make the butterfly wander around. * *Bonus:* Use additional behaviors to make the butterfly appear more life-like.

authored_hints.behavior_list: Try using behaviors such as "moving east and looping", "spinning right", and "wandering".

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make a prediction!
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
Make a prediction! Study the code.

-   The sprite will just spin right.
-   The sprite will just move east.
-   The sprite will spin and move at the same time.
-   The sprite will spin first and then move later.

callouts.behaviors_edit: Click here to see how this behavior works.

answers.text: The sprite will just spin right.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The sprite will also move east.

answers.text: The sprite will just move east.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The sprite has not stopped spinning, so it will do both simultaneously.

answers.text: The sprite will spin and move at the same time.
answers.feedback: Correct! Both behaviors will happen simultaneously.

answers.text: The sprite will spin first and then move later.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. In Sprite Lab, connected blocks happen immediately after each the last one, so both behaviors will happen simultaneously.

questions.text: Read the code, then make a prediction.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make a sprite, then change its size and give it a behavior.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Quick Review
[expandable][0]
In this lesson, we'll be doing more with sprites and behaviors. First, let's practice what you learned in the last lesson. ## Do This - Make a sprite. - Set the sprite's size. - Begin any behavior.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make the sprite begin a second behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Time Events
[expandable][0]
Events make it easy to change what happens over time as your program runs. Use an [blockly block][1] event to make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed. ## Do This - Add an `at 3 seconds` event block to your workspace. - Connect a `sprite begins` block under this event. The sprite should begin a second behavior after some time has passed.

callouts.events_category: Click here to open the Events category.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make the sprite's size, position, or rotation change when the user presses a key.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Key Events
[expandable][0]
Events make it possible to create programs that are interactive. Use the [blockly block][1] event block to change the sprite's _size_, _position_, or _rotation_ when the user presses a key. ## Do This - Add a `when key pressed` **event** block to your workspace. - Connect a `change` block under this event. - Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run.

authored_hints.changePropBlock:
You will also need this block:

[blockly block][0]

callouts.whenKey: Use the new event block found here.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make the sprite move one way, then another way.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Switching Behaviors
[expandable][0]
If you want to switch from one behavior to another, you need to _stop_ the old behavior and _begin_ the new behavior at the same time. You can use a new block to make sprites stop their current behaviors. [blockly block][1] You'll need to connect a behavior to this block, such as `moving east`. ## Do This - Run the code and see what happens. - Add behaviors to each `stops` and `begins` block to make the sprite change from moving east to moving west at 2 seconds.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Make the sprite spin one way, then another way.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Opposite Behaviors
[expandable][0]
Some behaviors do opposite things, like `moving east`/`moving west`, `growing`/`shrinking`, or `spinning right`/`spinning left`. If a sprite has two opposite behaviors it might seem like the sprite isn't do anything at all. ## Do This - Run the code and see what happens at 3 seconds. - Add a `sprite stops` block under the event. - Use this block to stop the old behavior. _The sprite should now spin one way, then another way._

You can use the descriptions below to help students self-select choices, or to set expectations around how many sub-levels they should complete.

courseF_events_ship.bubble_choice_description: Make the ship move after a few second have passed. Practice adding behaviors with events.
courseF_events_ship.short_instructions: Use an event to make the ship begin moving forward after 8 seconds.
courseF_events_ship.long_instructions:
#Blast Off!
![expandable](https://images.code.org/6a56375157dd2aabfb255e29cd717cbc-image-1611082032886.2021-01-19 13_46_53.gif)
This ship is ready to go! Use an "seconds"8 event to make the ship begin moving forward after 8 seconds. ## Do This * Add an `at 8 seconds` event block to your workspace. * Connect a `sprite begins` block under this event. * Give the sprite a behavior to make it "blast off" (move right) across the screen after 8 seconds.

courseF_events_practice_reorder.bubble_choice_description: A problem in this code is stopping the bird. Get the code into the right order.
courseF_events_practice_reorder.short_instructions: Change the order of the code underneath "at 2 seconds" so that the sprite only stops the old behaviors.
courseF_events_practice_reorder.long_instructions:
# Debug - Order Matters
![expandable](https://images.code.org/b4bcc1189e8989642002b387cfc5fed8-image-1611261721470.2021-01-21 15_40_45.gif)
There is a bug in this code. ## Do This * Run the code to see what happens. Click below to read about the bug.
What's the bug?After 2 seconds, the bird should fly away. Instead, it just stops.
* Change the order of the code underneath `at 2 seconds` so that the sprite only stops the **old** behaviors.

callouts.stopAllBug: This block is in the wrong order.

courseF_events_choice_conflict.bubble_choice_description: Make the plane spin one way, and the other. Practice controlling behaviors with events.
courseF_events_choice_conflict.short_instructions: Make the plane sprite spin left when you press one key, and right when you press the other key.
courseF_events_choice_conflict.long_instructions:
# Do a Barrel Roll!
![expandable](https://images.code.org/08b3e8a6ed02260555675174a0a41c13-image-1611354854787.2021-01-22 17_33_41.gif)
Let's make the plane sprite spin left when you press one key, and right when you press the other key. Do you remember this block? "creature_18_1" ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and press both arrows to see what happens.
What's the bug?When you press the first arrow key, the plane spins, but the program stops working when you press the second arrow key.
* Add an `sprite stops` block under each event. * Use this block to stop the opposite behavior. *The sprite should now spin in either direction when you press each arrow key.*

courseF_events_choice_conflict2.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite change sizes with the arrow keys. Practice controlling behaviors with events.
courseF_events_choice_conflict2.short_instructions: Make the sprite shrink when you press one key, and grow when you press the other key.
courseF_events_choice_conflict2.long_instructions:
# Shrink and Grow
![expandable](https://images.code.org/ee8148a40007249560471e6a99b537e3-image-1611697250512.2021-01-26 16_38_41.gif)
Let's make the sprite shrink when you press one key, and grow when you press the other key. Do you remember this block? "creature_05_1" ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and press both arrows to see what happens.
What's the bug?When you press an arrow key, the sprite begins one behavior. When you press the second arrow key, the sprite seems to stop responding.
* Add an `sprite stops` block under each event. * Use this block to stop the opposite behavior. *The sprite should now shrink or grow when you press each arrow key.*

courseF_events_choice_pufferfish.bubble_choice_description: Make the pufferfish quickly expand in size! Practice using events.
courseF_events_choice_pufferfish.short_instructions: Use the "while key pressed" event block to repeatedly change the sprite's size while the user presses a key.
courseF_events_choice_pufferfish.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
![expandable](https://images.code.org/ecd2788bd12f594a846de079ed22f484-image-1611328367728.2021-01-22 10_12_02.gif)
The when/while??? block has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. Use the `when/while key pressed` event block to repeatedly change the sprite's *size* while the user presses a key. ## Do This * Add a `key pressed` event to your workspace. Set it to either "when" or while". * Connect a `change size by` **action** block under this event. * Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run. *Extra Challenge:* Make the sprite get bigger when you press "up" and smaller when you press "down".

authored_hints.changeProp:
You will also need this block:

<xml><block type="gamelab_changePropBy">
      <title name="PROPERTY">"scale"</title>
      <value name="SPRITE">
        <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
          <title name="ANIMATION">"creature_18_1"</title>
        </block>
      </value>
      <value name="VAL">
        <block type="math_number">
          <title name="NUM">5</title>
        </block>
      </value>
    </block></xml>

courseF_events_choice_penguin.bubble_choice_description: Make a sprite move around using the arrow keys.
courseF_events_choice_penguin.short_instructions: Change each "when key pressed" block to "while key pressed" to make the sprite's movement faster and smoother.
courseF_events_choice_penguin.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
![expandable](https://images.code.org/a81a5d5487327d7783540239d87a988e-image-1611351171916.2021-01-22 16_31_44.gif)
The when/while??? has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. The `when key pressed` event block makes the sprite move with the keys, but it feels slow and clunky. ## Do This * Run the program and press the arrow keys to see how the sprite moves. * Change each `when key pressed` block to `while key pressed` to make the sprite's movement faster and smoother.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Quick Review
[expandable][0]
In this lesson, we'll be learning a lot about adding text to your project. Before that, let's practice something you've already learned. ## Do This - Make two sprites with different costumes. - Give each sprite a different location.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Use the "print" block to make text appear on the screen.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Printing Text
[expandable][0]
To make text appear on the screen you can use the print block: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Find the `print` block in the **World** category and add it to your program. - Type a message into the right side of the block to make that text appear above your sprites. _You might print text for lots of reasons:_ - _To make characters talk._ - _To describe a scene._ - _To give instructions for a game._

callouts.text_print_finish: Did your message print above? If so, hit 'Finish'. If not, hit 'Reset', change your code, and hit 'Run' again.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Use events to make more text appear on the screen over time.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Using Text with Events
[expandable][0]
To make more text appear on the screen over time, you'll need to use events. ## Do This - Choose any block from the **Events** category and add it to your program. - Connect a new `print` block under the event. - Run your program and make the second message appear after the first. _Changing text over time makes your project more engaging:_ - _Characters can have a conversation._ - _You can tell a story._

callouts.events_category: Click here to open the Events category.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Add a prompt to the screen.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Prompts (Part 1)
[expandable][0]
It's time to start learning how to use **prompts**. Prompts make it possible to get words and other text from the user and use them later in your program. The text the user types into the prompt is stored in a **variable**. [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Find the `prompt user` block in the **World** category and add it to your program. - In the top part of the block, type in a question you'd like to ask. - Change `???` to the label you want to use by clicking "**Rename this variable**." - Press "Run", then answer the prompt by typing something in. _Nothing else will happen yet, but that's okay!_

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Use the "when answered" block to print the text from the variable after the prompt is answered.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Prompts (Part 2)
[expandable][0]
To use the information stored in the variable, we first need to wait for the user to answer. You now have a new event block that is triggered as soon as a prompt is answered: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Drag the new `when answered` block into your program. Make sure the variable name matches the one in your prompt! - Connect a `print` block under this new event. - Make sure all the variable labels match! - Press "Run", then type something into the prompt. _Whatever message you type should be printed to the top of the screen._

callouts.answered_block: Look for a new block here!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Combine the text stored in variables with other text.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Prompts (Part 3)
[expandable][0]
Now let's get a little fancier. You can combine the text stored in variables with other text: [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Look through the new blocks in the **World** category. - Use these blocks with your `print` block so that it combines other text with the text from the variable. - You might want to change the question you are asking or the label of your variable. _This level is challenging! Click the lightbulb to the left if you would like to see an example._

dsls.teacher_markdown:
# Choice Level Overview
Choice levels provide a menu of additional levels for students to complete. Students must complete at least one of the sub-levels here, but may work through as many as they (or you) like.

You can use the descriptions below to help students self-select choices, or to set expectations around how many sub-levels they should complete.

|                  |Using Speech for Text|Text from Prompts|Name the robot!|Variable Labels|Big Text|Prompting for colors|Starting from scratch|
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
| ***Type*** |**Review**|**Debug**|**Debug**|**Debug**|**Optional Content**|**Optional Content**|**Free Play**
| ***Concept***|*print block, events*|*prompts, events*|*adding spaces*|*matching variable labels*|*title screen blocks*|*storing colors*|*no new content*

courseF_text_choice_conversation.bubble_choice_description: Use `print` blocks to make two sprites have a conversation.
courseF_text_choice_conversation.short_instructions: Use the `print` block to make two characters have a conversation.
courseF_text_choice_conversation.long_instructions:
# Using Text for Speech
![expandable](https://images.code.org/f73bba63225ef175eefb47711312be38-image-1612991318889.2021-02-10 16_08_23.gif)
Let's use the `print` block to make two characters have a conversation. This program has been started for you. You can just add `print` blocks to it or you can make any other changes you like! ## Do This * Place a `print` block under each `at seconds` block. * Type in your own text to make the animals have a conversation.

callouts.text_generic_finish: Are you finished? If so, hit 'Finish'. If not, hit 'Reset', change your code, and hit 'Run' again.

courseF_text_choice_events.short_instructions: Add an event block so the text gets printed correctly.
courseF_text_choice_events.long_instructions:
# Printing text from prompts
![expandable](https://images.code.org/8d6cd66b4ebacaa59813be4e4fe5ce4e-image-1613752356135.png)
This program has been started for you, but there is a bug. The text is getting printed too early! ## Do This * Read the code carefully and Run the program to see what happens. * Add a `when answered` block to your workspace. * Rearrange your code so the text from the prompt prints correctly at the right time.

courseF_text_choice_interview.bubble_choice_description: A mistake in the code is messing up what the robot is saying. Find and fix the mistake.
courseF_text_choice_interview.short_instructions: Fix the bug so the text prints correctly.
courseF_text_choice_interview.long_instructions:
# Joining Text with Variables
![expandable]()
This program has a bug that makes the text get printed incorrectly. Run the program without changing anything to see what's wrong, then try fixing the problem! Greetings! My name is name the robot! ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and enter a name to see what happens.
What's the bug?The text that gets printed should have spaces around the name, but the spaces are missing.
* Fix the bug.

courseF_text_choice_multiprompt.bubble_choice_description: A mistake in the code is messing up this greeting card. Find and fix the mistake.
courseF_text_choice_multiprompt.short_instructions: Fix the bug so the text prints correctly.
courseF_text_choice_multiprompt.long_instructions:
# Variable Labels
![expandable]()
Each time you use a variable, the label (like "name" or "age") should match. This program has **two** prompts, but the text doesn't get printed because of a mistake with variable labels. Run the program without changing anything to see what's wrong, then try fixing the problem! ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and enter a name and age to see what happens.
What's the bug?The `when answered` block uses the wrong variable, so the text is never displayed.
* Fix the bug so that all the text gets printed correctly.

authored_hints.when_answered_var:
Try changing the label of the variable in the `when answered` block. Because there are multiple prompts, use the label for the *last* prompt that will be answered.

<xml><block type="gamelab_whenPromptAnswered">
      <value name="VAR">
        <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
          <title name="VAR">???</title>
        </block>
      </value>
    </block></xml>

![expandable]()
You can add big text to your program with a title screen. This block makes the text appear until you replace it or hide it. In this level, you'll use two new blocks.
## Do This * Make a program that displays a title screen, and then hides it *at 3 seconds*.

dsls.markdown: # Stop! ## Are you sure you're ready to move on? In the next level, you will begin writing the code for your project. This works best if you already have a plan. Your completed plan should include: * The type of project you're building. For example, a greeting card, chatbot, or blank space story. * A list of questions you will ask the user. * The other text you will display to the screen. * A description or drawing of the sprites you will need (and their behaviors). If you are not sure if you are ready to move on, check with your teacher!

dsls.description: You will be creating either a greeting card, a chatbot, or a blank space story. If you have already finished \"Part 1\" of your project, go on to \"Part 2\".
dsls.teacher_markdown:
# Choice Level Overview
Choice levels provide a menu of additional levels for students to complete. Students must complete at least one of the sub-levels here, but should be encouraged to complete **two** levels for the same project.

Students may need really clear instructions to understand how to navigate the choices here. For each of the project choices, there are two sub-levels here. To begin, students should pick one of the levels marked "Part 1". Once they finish that level they should return here and select "Part 2" of the *same* project. The first level for each choice will provide students with feedback as they put the basic components of their project together. The second level is a "free play" which is intended to allow students to make any changes to their code that they like.

courseF_variables_card.bubble_choice_description: Create your first prompt, then add sprites and behaviors.
courseF_variables_card.long_instructions:
# Create a Customized Greeting Card You can use Sprite Lab to create a customized greeting for a holiday or special occasion. Using variables, your card will ask the user questions and then display a customized message. Create your program below. This works best if you already have a plan to follow.
![expandable]()
## Requirements * Your program needs to ask the user at least one question. * Your program needs to print text from at least one variable. * Your program needs to include sprites with behaviors. You can also add whatever you like to your code, including backgrounds, sounds, and more.

courseF_variables_card_finish.bubble_choice_description: Put the finishing touches on your project, then share it!
courseF_variables_card_finish.long_instructions:
# Finish Your Greeting Card

*You should have already started building your greeting card program. If you haven't, return to the [previous level](../sublevel/1).*


You can now add whatever you like to your code. You card can ask the user multiple questions and respond will a message for each one. You can make your program more interactive, by changing the behaviors of your sprite with each event, or by adding sounds and backgrounds. If you would like a new idea, click the lightbulb to the left.

authored_hints.card_idea1:
You can add a second (or third or fourth) prompt by connecting a new prompt block with a different variable to your first `when answered` event.

<xml><block type="gamelab_whenPromptAnswered">
    <value name="VAR">
      <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
        <title name="VAR">name</title>
      </block>
    </value>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_setPrompt">
        <value name="QUESTION">
          <block type="text" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
            <title name="TEXT">what do you want for your birthday?</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="VAR">
          <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
            <title name="VAR">gift</title>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block></xml>
authored_hints.card_idea2:
You can have a change from one behavior to another by using a `sprite stops` block with a `sprite begins` block under an event.

<xml><block type="gamelab_whenPromptAnswered">
    <value name="VAR">
      <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
        <title name="VAR">name</title>
      </block>
    </value>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_removeBehaviorSimple">
        <value name="SPRITE">
          <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
            <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="BEHAVIOR">
          <block type="gamelab_behavior_get">
            <mutation></mutation>
            <title name="VAR" id="spinning left">spinning left</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <next>
          <block type="gamelab_addBehaviorSimple">
            <value name="SPRITE">
              <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
                <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
              </block>
            </value>
            <value name="BEHAVIOR">
              <block type="gamelab_behavior_get">
                <mutation></mutation>
                <title name="VAR" id="spinning right">spinning right</title>
              </block>
            </value>
          </block>
        </next>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block>
</xml>
authored_hints.card_idea3:
You can make your program interactive by making other things happen when the user presses a key or after a certain amount of time has passed.

<xml><block type="gamelab_keyPressed">
    <title name="CONDITION">"when"</title>
    <title name="KEY">"up"</title>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_changePropBy">
        <title name="PROPERTY">"scale"</title>
        <value name="SPRITE">
          <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
            <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="VAL">
          <block type="math_number">
            <title name="NUM">10</title>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block></xml>

courseF_variables_chatbot.bubble_choice_description: Create your first prompt, then add sprites and behaviors.
courseF_variables_chatbot.long_instructions:
# Create a Chatbot A chatbot is a computer program that simulates human conversation. Using variables, you can create a chatbot that asks a user questions and then responds. Create your program below. This works best if you already have a plan to follow.
![expandable]()
## Requirements * Your program needs to ask the user at least one question. * Your program needs to print text from at least one variable. * Your program needs to include sprites with behaviors. You can also add whatever you like to your code, including backgrounds, sounds, and more.

courseF_variables_chatbot_finish.bubble_choice_description: Put the finishing touches on your project, then share it!
courseF_variables_chatbot_finish.long_instructions:
# Finish Your Chatbot

*You should have already started building your chatbot program. If you haven't, return to the [previous level](../sublevel/3).*


You can now add whatever you like to your code. A chatbox should ask the user multiple questions and respond to each one. You can make your program more interactive, by changing the behaviors of your sprite with each event, or by adding sounds and background. courseF_variables_madlib.short_instructions: Create an interactive blank space story!
courseF_variables_madlib.long_instructions:
# Create a blank space story! You can use Sprite Lab to create to bring your own blank space story to life. Using variables, your project will ask the user for words that get worked into a silly story. Create your program below. This works best if you already have a plan to follow. You will also need to draw your own sprite costume, or add a new one that you like. Look for the "*People*" category!*

People

## Requirements * Your program needs to ask the user at least one question. * Your program needs to print text from at least one variable. * Your program needs to include sprites with behaviors. You can also add whatever you like to your code, including backgrounds, sounds, and more.

courseF_variables_madlib_finish.short_instructions: Finish your customized blank space story.
courseF_variables_madlib_finish.long_instructions:

*You should have already started building your interactive blank space story. If you haven't, return to the [previous level](../sublevel/5).*


You can now add whatever you like to your code. Ask the user for multiple words, and use each one in a story you print to the screen. You can make your program more interactive, by changing the behaviors of your sprite with each event, or by adding sounds and backgrounds. If you would like a new idea, click the lightbulb to the left.

This level is a free play. These levels have some characteristics you may want to explore before starting.

dsls.markdown:
# Outbreak: Code Your Own Simulation ## Welcome to Monster Town! Monster Town was usually a happy and healthy place. The monsters of Monster town loved to wander around to visit their friends. One day, one of the monsters started feeling sick. The monster had caught a **virus**! A virus is a tiny germ that can make you sick. The other monsters were not too worried. They kept visiting their friends. Soon after, two more monsters got sick. It was the same virus! It seems they got the virus from their friend. The virus slowly spread to other monsters who were nearby. The healthy monsters began to worry that they were all going to get sick. The sick monsters began to worry that they were going to give the virus to everyone else.
## Stopping the spread Fortunately, after studying the virus, the neighbors of Monster Town made an important discovery. They realized that they were less likely to spread the virus if they wore masks over their mouths. With face masks on, sick monsters were less likely to give the virus to healthy monsters.
## What will happen next? Today, you're going to write code to create and run your own **simulation** of the virus outbreak at Monster Town. A simulation is a computer model of a process or system. Learn to code and make predictions about what will happen to the neighbors of Monster Town. * *How quickly will the virus spread?* * *Will everyone get sick?* * *How will face masks help?* When you're finished, share your simulation with others. Share your message about what you think we can do to help keep others healthy when a virus comes to town.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Creating a Simulation
_Today, you're going to write code so you can run your own simulation of the virus outbreak at Monster Town._ _First, we will bring Monster Town to life by creating sprites to represent the monsters. Write your code in the_ **workspace,** _then press_ **Run** _to see your simulation. If you need any help, click the_ **lightbulb** _for a hint._
## Do This 1. Make sprites to represent 10 healthy monsters [][0] and 1 sick monster [][1]. **Sprites** are the characters on the screen that can move, change, or interact with each other. 2. Set the size of the sprites to `50`, and make them all begin `wandering`. 3. Press `RUN`. You should see sprites moving around like the animation to the right.

# Programming with Events
_ Uh oh! One of the monsters caught a virus! When a healthy monster touches a sick monster, it becomes sick too._
To make something happen when two sprites touch, we will use this "event" block: [blockly block][0] Notice that you can open this block with the blue `+` on the left side. ## Do This Use the `subject` block inside to change **healthy monsters** [][1] into **sick monsters** [][2] when they touch.

Monsters with face masks will be unable to get the virus or give it to others. To make something happen when a type of monster is clicked, you can use a new type of_ "event" _block._ ## Do This 1. Use a `when clicked` block with the `change costume` block to give healthy monsters a mask when they are clicked. Repeat this for sick monsters. 2. Press `Run` and begin rapidly clicking the monsters. Try to slow or stop the outbreak by putting a mask on all the monsters.

dsls.markdown: # Outbreak: Thinking Like a Scientist Simulations are a great way to learn things that can be hard to observe in the real world. They help scientists solve problems and test new ideas safely and efficiently. Your simulation is a way to show how a virus outbreak in Monster Town might look. ## Reset and Replay! Even when you write the code yourself, it's impossible to know exactly what will happen when you press run. The monsters wander randomly, so you don't know if the virus will spread fast or slow. Whenever you change your code, make sure to run your simulation more than once. Things won't happen the same way twice! ## Collecting Data Try writing down your observations as you run your simulation. You can count the number of monsters that get sick or use a timer to see how fast things happen. For example, how long does it usually take for all monsters to get sick if none have masks? ## Making Predictions If you understand your model, you can use it to make predictions. You can even change how your simulation runs and guess what will happen differently. For example: * What would happen if there were twice as many monsters? * What would happen if the monsters moved at half the speed? ## Is Monster Town like the real world? There is a limit to how realistic any model can get. * What does your outbreak simulation have in common with real world virus outbreaks? * What are the differences? When you finish this activity, discuss these questions with teachers or your family! ## What else can we model? You have already created a working model of the outbreak at Monster Town. What are the things your simulation can't do or show that you wish it could? Press continue to keep going and learn to model even more: * Increasing the number of monsters in the simulation * Helping monsters recover from the virus * Probability, immunity, vaccines, and more! You can also share your simulation model with others, or share a message about what you think we can do to help keep others healthy when a virus comes to town.

# Recovery
_Good news: Monsters can now start to feel better on their own! Sick monsters that begin recovering will automatically change back to a healthy monster after some time passes. How do you think this will affect the outbreak?_
## Do This Run the simulation a few more times. Did anything happen differently?

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.bubble_choice_description: A virus isn't always transmitted, and masks don't stop transmission perfectly either. Improve your simulation by making infections happen with a random chance.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.short_instructions: Add a percent chance for monsters to get sick whenever healthy monsters touch sick monsters. Do this for all combinations of monsters with and without masks.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Chance
_Right now, it's impossible for monsters to give or get the virus if either of them is wearing a mask. This sounds great, but it's not really that simple. We should add a "chance" (or probability) for the virus to spread each time any two monsters touch. We can model the chance of getting the virus off of these notes._
Notes:How face masks affect the Monster Town outbreak

_Benefits of Face Masks_ | Healthy | Sick | Chance | | :-----: | :---: | :-----------: | | [][6] | [][7] | **Very High** | | [][4] | [][5] | **High** | | [][2] | [][3] | **Low** | | [][0] | [][1] | **Very Low** |

## Do This 1. Add this **logic** block under the `when touches` event and set it to a very high chance: [blockly block][8] 2. Add more events that include monsters wearing masks and give each a different percent chance (probability). Click the lightbulb for a hint if you are not sure which events are needed. 3. Press **Finish** when you are ready to move on.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2021/l.long_instructions:
# Vaccines
_Vaccines can protect monsters from getting a virus. These monsters will not get sick at all!_
Next, you will create a new sprite costume to represent monsters who got a vaccine.
Learn how to modify a sprite costume. | | To modify a costume: | | ------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [expandable][0]
(Click to view) | 1. Change to the Costumes tab in the top left corner.
2. Duplicate one of the existing costumes.
3. Choose a primary color for drawing.
4. Click the Paint bucket tool, then click the monster's body to recolor it. |
Once the new costume is ready, find a way to work it into your program. For example, you can change masked monsters into vaccinated monsters when they are clicked.
